abstract.text: An interaction that provides edit operations using a menu.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Edit menu interactions provide edit actions — such as cut, copy, and paste — for the content a view displays. The presentation style the interaction uses to display the actions conforms to the input method of the interaction. For touch interactions, the actions display in an editing menu. When responding to a secondary click on devices with pointer-based input, the actions display in a context menu.
, are preconfigured to use edit menu interactions.
To add an edit menu interaction to a generic view:
Create an edit menu interaction object, and pass an optional delegate into the default initializer.
method on your view to add the interaction.
Create a gesture recognizer to trigger the interaction and add it to the view.
The following example creates an edit menu interaction triggered by a long press.

code: let configuration = UIEditMenuConfiguration(identifier: nil, sourcePoint: location)

inlineContent.text: By default, an edit menu interaction generates a menu that includes commands for the standard edit actions your view implements. For more information on these actions, see
. You can use the interaction’s delegate to add additional items to the menu and set the target rectangle to display around using methods in the
protocol. For text views, you can specify the items the menu displays for specific text ranges using methods from the

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An object containing the configuration details for the menu your app presents in response to an edit menu interaction.
An interaction that provides edit operations using a menu.
An object that customizes presentation of the menu and actions to display for an edit menu interaction.
Dismiss the edit menu if present.
Initializes an edit menu interaction object with the delegate object you specify.
Returns the location of the user interaction in the specified view’s coordinate system.
Presents an edit menu using the object you provide for configuration.
Updates the actions an edit menu displays.
Updates the position of the currently visible menu with an option to animate the action.
The methods for customizing the menu the interaction displays.
The protocol that an interaction implements to access the view that owns it.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
An object that displays an editable text area in your interface.
A set of optional methods to manage editing and validating text in a text field object.
A set of methods for interacting with the text input system and enabling features in documents.
A scrollable, multiline text region.
The methods for receiving editing-related messages for text view objects.
Adds an interaction to the view.
Optimize your iPad app’s user experience by adopting desktop-class enhancements for multitasking with Stage Manager, document interactions, text editing, search, and more in iPadOS 16.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
